intro: Obione novae-zelandiae, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the Asphodelaceae family and is characterized by its tall, grass-like leaves that can grow up to several meters in length. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in summer, followed by distinctive, three-lobed seed pods. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in forest margins and wetlands. Due to its historical and cultural significance, it is also valued for its fibrous leaves used in traditional Māori weaving.
